section.title: First Steps
section.para: This tutorial teaches you how to get started in programming on the gDesklets platform. It is an updated and revised version of the former HOWTO "How to Make Desklets" by Martin Grimme.

section.title: The Parts of a Desklet
section.para: Each desklet consists of a window which contents are defined in a .display file (which is in plain XML). Controls are used to interact with the system.
You can easily create new desklets without any programming knowledge by using existing controls in a new .display file. The first part of this tutorial will teach you how.
Now, let's dive into the wonderful world of desklets and have fun!

section.title: The "Hello World!" Desklet
section.para: We will begin with the obligatory "Hello World!" desklet, which is very easy with gDesklets. Save the .display file as hello.display and load it into gDesklets. This is a simple static desklet without interaction.
section.programlisting:
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>
<display window-flags="sticky" bg-color="white"> <label value="Hello, World of Desklets!" font="Serif 20" color="red"/> </display>
section.para: The example uses the two elements <display> (the display window) and <label> (a text label). Elements can be configured by setting properties on them. We want the display to be sticky (visible on all virtual desktops), so we set the window-flag to sticky. You can look up the available properties of each element in the reference part of this book.

Every visual element can be positioned by giving the x and y properties. Because 0 is the default value for the coordinates, you can omit setting these properties in the label if it should be positioned at (0, 0).

section.title: Grouping of Elements
section.para: If you have already worked with vector based drawing programs, you probably know the principle of grouping: several objects behave as if they were one object and can be moved around as a whole. The <group> container element in gDesklets basically does the same.
Take a look at the following example. It illustrates how to group targets together so that they can be positioned as one big object.
section.programlisting:
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>
<display window-flags="sticky" bg-color="white"> <label value="#1"/>
<group x="20" y="20" bg-color="green"> <label x="0" y="0" value="#2"/> <label x="0" y="50" value="#3"/> <label x="50" y="0" value="#4"/> </group> </display>
section.para: Now play around with the x and y coordinate values of the group and watch what happens with the labels #2, #3, #4.
Some container elements accept only a single child. The group counts as a single element, no matter what it contains. So it can be used to put complex things into such containers.

As you have already seen, you can set the background of a group. You can create empty groups just to make color bars. Use the width and height properties to set their size, since an empty group without a given size will collapse immediately in order to take only as much space as its (non-existent) children would need.
section.programlisting:
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>
<display window-flags="sticky" bg-color="white" width="310" height="20"> <group bg-color="navy" x="5" y="5" width="300" height="10"/> </display>

section.title: Relative Positioning
section.para: Get ready for learning about one of the most powerful positioning techniques for display elements: relative positioning.

Until now, you have placed elements by using fixed coordinates. But usually you often don't know what the correct coordinate values are. Imagine you want to place a percent sign next to a numeric value. The value could have one to three digits, so there is no fixed position for the percent sign. It should instead be place relative to the position of the numeric value. This is where the relative-to property comes into play.
Possible relative positionings are right to the other element, below it, or below to the right of it. The appropriate values for relative-to are "id, x", "id, y", and "id, xy", respectively.

The x and y coordinate properties can still be used but are then interpreted as if the origin where on the right, left, or bottom edge of the other element, respectively. Negative values may be used as well for overlapping effects. You can use anchors (see XXX) for a finer control of relative positioning.
Let's take a look at the example with the percent sign to see how it is done:
section.programlisting:
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>
<display window-flags="sticky" bg-color="white"> <label id="fill" value="95" font="Serif 32"/> <label relative-to="fill, x" value="%" font="Serif 32"/> </display>
section.para: This looks quite unspectacular, but whenever the width of the numeric value label changed, the position of the percent sign would dynamically adjust to the right place.

section.title: Positioning Anchors
section.para: When you set the coordinates of an element, its top left corner will usually go to the specified position. This is because the default positioning anchor is the top left corner. There are nine positioning anchors available in total:

itemizedlist.listitem: n - middle of the top edge
e - middle of the right edge
s - middle of the bottom edge
w - middle of the left edge

section.para: You can change the positioning anchor by setting the anchor to one of the nine values above. The following example illustrates the result of each anchor position. The coordinate values of all labels are (50, 50), but they all have different positions.
section.programlisting:
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>
<display window-flags="sticky" bg-color="white" width="100" height="100"> <label x="50" y="50" anchor="nw" value="NW" font="Serif 20" color="red"/> <label x="50" y="50" anchor="n" value="N" font="Serif 20" color="green"/> <label x="50" y="50" anchor="ne" value="NE" font="Serif 20" color="blue"/> <label x="50" y="50" anchor="e" value="E" font="Serif 20" color="yellow"/> <label x="50" y="50" anchor="se" value="SE" font="Serif 20" color="purple"/> <label x="50" y="50" anchor="s" value="S" font="Serif 20" color="darkred"/> <label x="50" y="50" anchor="sw" value="SW" font="Serif 20" color="grey70"/> <label x="50" y="50" anchor="w" value="W" font="Serif 20" color="grey50"/> <label x="50" y="50" anchor="center" value="C" font="Serif 20" color="black"/> </display>

section.title: The Array
section.para: The array is a container elementes, which lets you create dynamically growing/shrinking displays like e.g. task bars. It consists of a set of similar child elements.

An array is used like a group that can only have one child element (a group with several children counts as one element and can of course be used in an array container). The following example creates a static array of several labels:
section.programlisting:
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>
<display window-flags="sticky" bg-color="#ffffffa0">
<array layout="vertical" length="10"> <label value="Text" font="16"/> </array>
</display>
section.para: By default, an array has no visible children. You can set the array length by using the length. The layout on the other hand, can be used for setting the layout of the child elements in the array, if you don't layout them yourself.
The next example shows you how you can control an array with inline scripting.
section.programlisting:
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>
<display bg-color="white">
<array id="myarray" layout="vertical" length="1"> <label value="Trapped inside an array."/> </array>
<group id="btn1" relative-to="myarray, y" bg-color="grey70" on-click="Dsp.myarray.length += 1"> <label value="Grow"/> </group>
<group relative-to="btn1, x" x="20" bg-color="grey70" on-click="if (Dsp.myarray.length != 1): Dsp.myarray.length -= 1"> <label value="Shrink"/> </group>
</display>

section.title: Meta Information
section.para: Display files can contain information about themselves and about their authors. It is not required to provide such data, but it is strongly recommended to do so! Applications, like the graphical shell, can parse this data and use it to show information about each display file.

Meta information is stored in the <meta> tag. This tag has to be a child of the <display> tag and is recognized by gDesklets since version 0.22. Older versions will complain that the <meta> tag is unknown, but otherwise still work.
The <meta> tag accepts a set of attributes which describe the display. The following example demonstrates the usage of the most common attributes:
section.programlisting:
<display>
<meta author="A. Nonymous" name="Cool Desklet" version="1.0" description="This is a very cool desklet. ^_^" preview="gfx/preview.png"/>
...
</display>
section.para: The preview attribute is e.g. used by the graphical shell to display preview images. You can lookup the valid meta attributes in the reference.
